Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $3,897.00 *
International Tuition: $17,641.00 **
Method of Study: Full-time
Location: Waterfront Campus
Program Offered By: Health Services Management (School)

Delivery Method Fall 2023: Hybrid (Semesters 1, 3)
Delivery Method Winter 2024: Hybrid (Semesters 1, 2, 4)

Context:
Extracted Information:

1. The program prepares students for effective communication in a medical office environment, teaching best practices related to active listening, effective writing for business communication, and oral communication skills.
2. In semester 4, students will have a field placement one day per week until the final two weeks of the program, with an intensive two-week placement period (five days per week).
3. Students may observe, shadow, and practice various technical and time-management skills required to manage day-to-day tasks in health services environments, including patient registration, appointment scheduling, reception duties, mail, forms, and records management, and working with applicable software and hardware.
4. Projects may involve adherence to confidentiality and privacy laws and require critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
5. To successfully complete the field placement component, students must demonstrate work-readiness behavior through exemplary attendance and punctuality, as well as professional conduct and attire.
6. Placement sites for the Office Administration – Health Services program include community and teaching hospitals, urgent care, long-term care facilities, clinics, diagnostic facilities, family practice, medical and surgical specialties, physiotherapy sports medicine specialists, chiropractors, and midwifery.
7. Career opportunities for graduates include positions as a receptionist, clerical assistant, office administrator, hospital unit clerk in a wide range of employment opportunities in the Health Services field, such as doctors' offices, clinics, hospitals, pharmaceutical companies, government agencies, and medical organizations.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Office Administration – Health Services Program S135 | George Brown College2023.txt

The text also mentions that the student may need to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000, and this course does not count as a required course for graduation. The student is advised to visit the Assessment Centre for more information.

Semesters: 2, 3, and 4.

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Conduct oneself professionally and adhere to relevant legislation, standards and codes of ethics.
2. Manage the scheduling, coordination and organization of administrative tasks and workflow within specific deadlines and according to set priorities.
3. Coordinate the collection, analysis, distribution and response to communications in the workplace to facilitate the flow of information.
4. Operate and provide support to others related to the use of office equipment and technologies.
5. Evaluate, establish and administer health records management systems to ensure confidential, secure, accessible and organized electronic and paper records.
6. Produce financial and client billing records for health services by compiling relevant information and using accounting software.
7. Produce health documents and reports using available technologies and applying industry standards.
8. Use interpersonal and client service skills to respond to the diverse needs of clients, their family members and the health care team.

Context:
The text mentions that this program requires client service skills and the ability to identify and use non-invasive clinical tasks. It also provides information on tuition fees for domestic and international students, financial assistance through OSAP for eligible applicants, and admission requirements such as having an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent with a grade 12 English (C or U), and the recommendation of attending an information session and having basic keyboarding skills. For mature students, taking the Admissions Assessment for English or upgrading to achieve the necessary English credits may be considered. The text also mentions course exemptions through college or university credits, special requirements including a Pre-placement Health Form for second-year students, and country-specific admission requirements for international students.

FACTUAL INFORMATION:
- Client service skills required
- Non-invasive clinical tasks required
- Domestic tuition: $3,897.00 (first two semesters, Fall 2022)
- International tuition: $17,641.00 (first two semesters, Fall 2023)
- OSAP funding available for eligible applicants
- Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent required
- Grade 12 English (C or U) required
- Information session recommended
- Basic keyboarding skills recommended
- Pre-placement Health Form required (for second-year students only)
- Country-specific admission requirements for international students
- Course exemptions possible through college or university credits

Context:
Students in this program are required to meet mandatory pre-placement health requirements, which may take up to four months to complete. The costs associated with these health requirements are the responsibility of the student. For details and to download the mandatory pre-placement health form, students should go to the Pre-placement website.

Second-year students must have a Police Vulnerable Sector Check completed, which typically takes two to three months but can take up to eight. Students are responsible for ensuring that their check covers appropriateness for individuals working with vulnerable persons. The fees for the police record check vary and must be paid by the student. For more information, please visit the Pre-placement website.

Students who are not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 may not be able to complete the required field placement component of their program in the regularly scheduled time frame. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. For more information, contact the School of Health Services Management at 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 or by email [h](mailto:h).

Pre-placement health requirements: yes
Police Vulnerable Sector Check: yes
COVID-19 vaccination: yes
Application process: yes
Contact information: School of Health Services Management (416-415-5000, ext. 2367, [h](mailto:h))
